Award.AwardTitle: Integration across episodes and languages: Developmental and educational implications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
An important goal of development is establishing a rich knowledge base to support educational and professional achievement. Much of the information that people have in their knowledge base they learned through direct instruction. Yet learners also go beyond what they are taught and integrate information across media (text, video) and across multiple experiences to generate new conclusions. Self-generation of knowledge is assumed to play an important role in education, allowing learners to extend the scope of each individual lesson. In spite of its presumed significance for education, self-generation has not been examined in the classroom. This research will test self-generation in the classroom and how it relates to academic achievement. The studies will take place 1) in traditional single-language classrooms and 2) in an increasing common educational model in which children learn through two languages (dual-language instruction). When content is presented in different languages, learners must integrate not only across media and time, but across languages as well. Understanding self-generation of knowledge in single- and dual-language classrooms, and how it relates to academic achievement, are the central goals of this research. The outcome will benefit society by helping to optimize educational practice in both traditional and dual-language settings.

The proposed work aims to examine integration and subsequent self-generation of information acquired in separate episodes in classroom environments. Concurrent and longitudinal individual difference measures of cognitive ability will be examined as possible underlying skills supporting knowledge extension in the classroom. Relations between knowledge generation and measures of academic performance also will be examined. Second, the study of self-generation will be extended into dual-language, an increasingly common model of education. Situations to be examined include information presented through different languages (English/Spanish) and information presented through the same language but tested in the alternate language. Finally, the work aims to address the paradox that in spite of presumed challenges to successful learning and extension of knowledge across language contexts, dual-language education has excellent academic outcomes. The expectation is that achievement of second-language proficiency minimizes the conceptual distance between to-be-integrated materials, supporting cross-language integration. Ultimately, the research will inform the underlying mechanisms necessary for self-generation of new knowledge through integration as well as how different language systems are represented and interact within an individual. The research has applied implications for educational practice in both dual-language and traditional education models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Educators employ many strategies to bestow information on learners, such as stories, demonstrations, and lectures. Learners are expected to collect information from these sources and further extend it through self-generataive processes such as inducation, deducation, and analogy. In controlled laboratory experiments, children as young as 4 years of age also extend knowledge through integration of separate yet related learning episodes, and self-deriving new knowledge from the newly integrated representations.

The present research took place not in the laboratory but in the classroom--an environment in which self-derivation is assumed to occur and seemingly necessary for success. The three objectives of the research were to: (a) test integration processes in the classroom; (b) further extend the study of self-generative processes into an increasingly common modl of education in which content is provided through multiple languages. Dual-language education is a highly efficient way of learning a 2nd language. Yet it could make integration more challenging, due to low surface-similarity between the episodes. We tested integration and self-derivation by childrden in dual-language education (English/Spanish) when information was presented through different languages. (c) test whether integration across languages was dependent on proficiency in one or both of the languages used.

We first examined self-derivation through integration in classrooms using a traditional (single language) education model of presentation of lessons through English. The 278 children were in Grades K-3. Children self-derived new factual knowledge through integration in the classroom; age-related increases were observed. Self-derivation performance predicted both reading comprehension and mathematics academic outcomes.

We next compared performance of children in traditional (English only) and dual-language (English/Spanish) classrooms. Children in Grades 1-2 heard story passages containing novel facts that could be integrated to self-derive new knowledge. There were no significant differences by education program (single vs. dual-language). The strongest predictor of self-derivation was English vocabulary, even for children in the dual-language education model. Children in Grades 3-4 heard novel facts in single sentences. For 3rd graders, integration across languages was associated with lower performance, relative to integration within a single language. In contrast, 4th graders' performance did not differ either between education models, or for children in dual-language education, in the same-language vs. cross-language conditions. There were not grade differences in either English or Spanish vocabulary. We suggest that the grade differences in performance be attributed to the greater experience the 4th graders had with cross-language integration and thus with the requirement to retrieve accumulated semantic knoweldge in the service of a task goal.
